alert.note: Alert for Foothills of the Blue Mountains of Washington; Lower Slopes of the Eastern Washington Cascades Crest; Northwest Blue Mountains; Simcoe Highlands; Upper Slopes of the Eastern Washington Cascades Crest (Washington) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Pendleton (Northeast Oregon and Southeast Washington)
info.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued April 07 at 2:24PM PDT by NWS Pendleton
info.description: ...RISES ON STREAMS AND RIVERS EXPECTED DUE TO SNOWMELT AND RAIN... Small streams and large rivers coming out of the mountains will see rises over the weekend and through the first half of next week. Showers this afternoon and evening may produce locally moderate to heavy precipitation, especially from the mountains of central Oregon through the eastern mountains of Oregon. A chance for more prolonged precipitation will begin Saturday across the Washington Cascades, spreading southeastward and encompassing much of the forecast area by Monday into Tuesday. Uncertainty lies in where exactly the band of heaviest precipitation will occur Monday and Tuesday, but expectation is that the largest rises in rivers, streams, and creeks will occur during this period. While only a few gauges are expected to even approach bankfull, much could change with the rain forecast between now and early next week. As of now, however, flooding is not expected to occur with this round of rainfall over the next several days. This Hydrologic Outlook will be updated again Saturday with the latest updates to the forecast.
